judgment: The Creative works sublime success, furthering through perseverance.
image: Heaven moves in ceaseless vigor. Thus the superior man makes himself strong and untiring.
lines: Hidden dragon. Do not act.
Dragon appearing in the field. It furthers one to see the great man.
All day long the superior man is creatively active. At nightfall his mind is still beset with cares. Danger. No blame.
Wavering flight over the depths. No blame.
Flying dragon in the heavens. It furthers one to see the great man.
Arrogant dragon will have cause to repent.

judgment: The Receptive brings about sublime success, furthering through the perseverance of a mare. If the superior man undertakes something and tries to lead, he goes astray; but if he follows, he finds guidance. It is beneficial to find friends in the west and south, to forego friends in the east and north. Quiet perseverance brings good fortune.
image: The earth's condition is receptive devotion. Thus the superior man who has breadth of character carries the outer world.
lines: When there is hoarfrost underfoot, solid ice is not far off.
Straight, square, great. Without purpose, yet nothing remains unfurthered.
Hidden lines. One is able to remain persevering.
A tied-up sack. No blame, no praise.
A yellow lower garment brings supreme good fortune.
Dragons fight in the meadow. Their blood is black and yellow.

judgment: Difficulty at the Beginning works supreme success, furthering through perseverance. Nothing should be undertaken. It furthers one to appoint helpers.
image: Clouds and thunder: The image of Difficulty at the Beginning. Thus the superior man brings order out of confusion.
lines: Hesitation and hindrance. It furthers one to remain persevering. It furthers one to appoint helpers.
Difficulties pile up. Horse and wagon part. He is not a robber; he wants to woo when the time comes. The maiden is chaste, she does not pledge herself. Ten years—then she pledges herself.
Whoever hunts deer without the forester only loses his way in the forest. The superior man understands the signs of the time and prefers to desist. To go on brings humiliation.
Horse and wagon part. Strive for union. To go brings good fortune. Everything acts to further.
Difficulties in blessing. Small perseverance brings good fortune. Great perseverance brings misfortune.
Horse and wagon part. Bloody tears flow.

judgment: Youthful Folly has success. It is not I who seek the young fool; The young fool seeks me. At the first oracle I inform him. If he asks two or three times, it is importunity. If he importunes, I give him no information. Perseverance furthers.
image: A spring wells up at the foot of the mountain: The image of Youth. Thus the superior man fosters his character by thoroughness in all that he does.
lines: To make a fool develop it furthers one to apply discipline. The fetters should be removed. To go on in this way brings humiliation.
To show forbearance toward the ignorant furthers. To take a girl to wife brings good fortune.
Take not a maiden who, when she sees a man of bronze, loses possession of herself. Nothing furthers.
Entangled folly brings humiliation.
Childlike folly brings good fortune.
In punishing folly it does not further one to commit transgressions. The only thing that furthers is to prevent transgressions.

judgment: Waiting. If you are sincere, you have light and success. Perseverance brings good fortune. It furthers one to cross the great water.
image: Clouds rise up to heaven: The image of Waiting. Thus the superior man eats and drinks, is joyous and of good cheer.
lines: Waiting in the meadow. It furthers one to abide in what endures. No blame.
Waiting on the sand. There is some gossip. The end brings good fortune.
Waiting in the mud brings about the arrival of the enemy.
Waiting in blood. Get out of the pit.
Waiting at meat and drink. Perseverance brings good fortune.
One falls into the pit. Three uninvited guests arrive. Honor them, and in the end there will be good fortune.

judgment: Conflict. You are sincere and are being obstructed. A cautious halt halfway brings good fortune. Going through to the end brings misfortune. It furthers one to see the great man. It does not further one to cross the great water.
image: Heaven and water go their opposite ways: The image of Conflict. Thus in all his transactions the superior man carefully considers the beginning.
lines: If one does not perpetuate the affair, there is a little gossip. In the end, good fortune comes.
One cannot engage in conflict; one returns home, gives way. The people of his town, three hundred households, remain free of guilt.
To nourish oneself on ancient virtue induces perseverance. Danger. In the end, good fortune comes. If by chance you are in the service of a king, seek not works.
One cannot engage in conflict. One turns back and submits to fate, changes one's attitude, and finds peace in perseverance. Good fortune.
To contend before him brings supreme good fortune.
Even if by chance a leather belt is bestowed on one, by the end of a morning it will have been snatched away three times.

judgment: The Army. The army needs perseverance and a strong man. Good fortune without blame.
image: In the middle of the earth is water: The image of the Army. Thus the superior man increases his masses by generosity toward the people.
lines: An army must set forth in proper order. If the order is not good, misfortune threatens.
In the midst of the army. Good fortune. No blame. The king bestows a triple decoration.
Perchance the army carries corpses in the wagon. Misfortune.
The army retreats. No blame.
There is game in the field. It furthers one to catch it. Without blame. Let the eldest lead the army. The younger transports corpses; then perseverance brings misfortune.
The great prince issues commands, founds states, vests families with fiefs.

judgment: Holding Together brings good fortune. Inquire of the oracle once again whether you possess sublimity, constancy, and perseverance; then there is no blame. Those who are uncertain gradually join. Whoever comes too late meets with misfortune.
image: On the earth is water: The image of Holding Together. Thus the kings of antiquity bestowed the different states as fiefs and cultivated friendly relations with the feudal lords.
lines: Hold to him in truth and loyalty; this is without blame. Truth, like a full earthen bowl: Thus in the end good fortune comes from without.
Hold to him inwardly. Perseverance brings good fortune.
You hold together with the wrong people.
Hold to him outwardly also. Perseverance brings good fortune.
Manifestation of holding together. In the hunt the king uses beaters on three sides only and foregoes game that runs off in front. The citizens need no warning. Good fortune.
He finds no head for holding together. Misfortune.

englishName: The Taming Power of the Small
judgment: The Taming Power of the Small has success. Dense clouds, no rain from our western region.
image: The wind moves above heaven: The image of The Taming Power of the Small. Thus the superior man refines the outward appearance.
lines: Return to the way. How could there be blame? Good fortune.
He allows himself to be drawn into returning. Good fortune.
Husband and wife turn against each other.
If you are sincere, blood will depart and fear will vanish. No blame.
If you are sincere, you are linked to others. Rich in your neighbor.
The rain comes, there is rest. The superior man goes. Misfortune.

judgment: Treading. Treading on the tail of the tiger. It does not bite the man. Success.
image: Heaven above, the lake below: The image of Treading. Thus the superior man discriminates between high and low, and thereby fortifies the people's will.
lines: Simple treading. Going on brings no blame.
Treading a smooth, level path. A dark man perseveres. Good fortune.
A one-eyed man is able to see; a lame man is able to tread. He treads on the tail of the tiger. The tiger bites the man. Misfortune. Thus does a warrior act for his great prince.
He treads on the tail of the tiger. Caution and circumspection lead to ultimate good fortune.
Resolute treading. Perseverance brings danger.
Look to your treading and consider the omens. If you are circumspect, supreme good fortune comes.

judgment: Peace. The small departs, the great approaches. Good fortune, success.
image: Heaven and earth unite: The image of Peace. Thus the ruler divides and completes the course of heaven and earth, and so aids the people.
lines: When ribbon grass is pulled up, the roots come with it. Each according to his kind. Undertakings bring good fortune.
Bearing with the uncultivated, Fording the river with resolution, Not neglecting what is distant, Associating with the mean, Thus one may manage to remain in the center.

No plain not followed by a slope, No going that does not bring return. He who remains persevering in danger is without blame. Do not complain about this truth; Enjoy the good fortune you still possess.
He flutters down, not boasting of his wealth before his neighbor. Sincere.
The sovereign Yi gives his daughter in marriage. This brings blessing and supreme good fortune.
The wall falls back into the moat. Do not use the army. In your own town, give your commands. Perseverance brings humiliation.

judgment: Standstill. Evil people do not further the perseverance of the superior man. The great departs, the small approaches.
image: Heaven and earth do not unite: The image of Standstill. Thus the superior man falls back upon his inner worth in order to escape the difficulties. He does not permit himself to be honored with revenue.
lines: When ribbon grass is pulled up, the roots come with it. Each according to his kind. Perseverance brings good fortune and success.
They bear and endure; this means good fortune for inferior people. The standstill is not caused by them.
They bear shame.
He who acts according to the mandate of heaven has no blame. His companions eat of the good fortune.
Standstill is giving way. The great man is fortunate. 'If it should perish, if it should perish!' Thus he ties it to a bush of mulberry.
The standstill comes to an end. First standstill, then good fortune.

judgment: Fellowship with Men in the open. Success. It furthers one to cross the great water. The perseverance of the superior man furthers.
image: Heaven together with fire: The image of Fellowship with Men. Thus the superior man organizes the clans and makes distinctions between things.
lines: Fellowship with men at the gate. No blame.
Fellowship with men in the clan. Humiliation.
He hides weapons in the thicket; he climbs the high hill. For three years he does not rise up.
He rides up on his city wall. He does not attack. Good fortune.
Fellowship with men. First weeping and lamenting, then laughing. After great struggles they succeed in meeting.
Fellowship with men in the open. No remorse.

judgment: Possession in Great Measure. Supreme success.
image: Fire in heaven above: The image of Possession in Great Measure. Thus the superior man curbs evil and furthers good, and thereby obeys the benevolent will of heaven.
lines: No relationship with what is harmful. No blame. If one remains conscious of difficulty, one remains free of error.
A great wagon for loading. One may undertake something. No blame.
A prince offers his gifts to the Son of Heaven. Small men are not capable of this.
He makes a difference between himself and his neighbor. No blame.
He is sincere and is linked to others. His dignity is glorious. Good fortune.
He is blessed by heaven. Good fortune. It furthers one to undertake something.

judgment: Modesty creates success. The superior man carries things through.
image: Within the earth, a mountain: The image of Modesty. Thus the superior man reduces that which is too much, and augments that which is too little. He weighs things and makes them equal.
lines: A superior man modest about his modesty may cross the great water. Good fortune.
Modesty that comes to expression. Perseverance brings good fortune.
A superior man of modesty and merit carries things to conclusion. Good fortune.
Nothing that would not further modesty in movement.
No boasting of wealth before one's neighbor. It furthers one to attack with force. Nothing that would not further.
Modesty that comes to expression. It furthers one to set armies marching to chastise one's own city and one's country.

judgment: Enthusiasm. It furthers one to appoint helpers and to set armies marching.
image: Thunder comes resounding out of the earth: The image of Enthusiasm. Thus the ancient kings made music in order to honor merit, and offered it with splendor to the Supreme Deity, inviting their ancestors to be present.
lines: Enthusiasm that expresses itself. Misfortune.
Firm as a rock. Not for a whole day. Perseverance brings good fortune.
Enthusiasm that looks upward brings remorse. Hesitation brings remorse.
The source of enthusiasm. He achieves great things. Doubt not. You gather friends around you as a hair clasp gathers the hair.
Persistently ill, yet he does not die.
Enthusiasm that is misled. But if one achieves completion, there is no blame.

judgment: Following. Supreme success. Perseverance furthers. No blame.
image: Thunder in the middle of the lake: The image of Following. Thus the superior man at nightfall goes indoors for rest and recuperation.
lines: The standard is changed. Perseverance brings good fortune. To go out of the door in order to achieve brings success.
If one clings to the little boy, one loses the strong man.
If one clings to the strong man, one loses the little boy. Through following one finds what one seeks. It furthers one to remain persevering.
Following creates success. Perseverance brings misfortune. To go forward with sincerity brings clarity. How could there be blame?
Sincerity in following is good. Good fortune.
He meets with sincerity and is bound to it. The king introduces him to the Western Mountain.

englishName: Work on What Has Been Spoiled
judgment: Work on What Has Been Spoiled has supreme success. It furthers one to cross the great water. Before the starting point, three days. After the starting point, three days.
image: The wind blows below the mountain: The image of Work on What Has Been Spoiled. Thus the superior man stirs up the people and strengthens their spirit.
lines: Setting right what has been spoiled by the father. If there is a son, no blame. The end brings good fortune.
Setting right what has been spoiled by the mother. One must not be too persevering.
Setting right what has been spoiled by the father. There will be a little remorse. No great blame.
Tolerating what has been spoiled. Humiliation.
Setting right what has been spoiled by the father. One meets with praise.
He does not serve kings and princes, but sets himself higher goals.

judgment: Approach has supreme success. Perseverance furthers. When the eighth month comes, there will be misfortune.
image: The earth above the lake: The image of Approach. Thus the superior man is inexhaustible in his will to teach, and without limits in his tolerance and protection of the people.
lines: Joint approach. Perseverance brings good fortune.
Joint approach. Good fortune. Everything acts to further.
Comfortable approach. Nothing that would further. If one is already saddened by it, one will be free of blame.
Complete approach. No blame.
Wise approach. This is appropriate for a great prince. Good fortune.
Greathearted approach. Good fortune.

judgment: Contemplation. The ablution has been made, but not yet the offering. Full of sincerity, one looks up to him.
image: The wind moves over the earth: The image of Contemplation. Thus the kings of old visited the regions of the world, contemplated the people, and gave them instruction.
lines: Childlike contemplation. For an inferior man, no blame. For a superior man, humiliation.
Contemplation through the crack of the door. It furthers the perseverance of a woman.
Contemplation of my life. He advances and retreats.
Contemplation of the light of the kingdom. It furthers one to be a guest of the king.
Contemplation of my life. The superior man is without blame.
Contemplation of his life. The superior man is without blame.

judgment: Biting Through has success. It is beneficial to use punishments.
image: Thunder and lightning: The image of Biting Through. Thus the kings of old clarified the laws through definite penalties.
lines: His feet are fettered. He disappears. No blame.
Biting through soft flesh. He disappears. No blame.
Biting through dried meat. He meets with something poisonous. Slight humiliation. No blame.
Biting through dried meat and finding metal arrows. It furthers one to be persevering. Misfortune. No blame.
Biting through dried meat. He finds yellow gold. He is persevering in his firmness. Danger. No blame.
His neck is in the wooden cangue. Misfortune.

judgment: Grace has success. In small matters it is beneficial to undertake something.
image: Fire at the foot of the mountain: The image of Grace. Thus the superior man gives proper attention to the various aspects of life, and thereby regulates his own life.
lines: He adorns his toes, leaves the carriage, and walks.
He adorns his beard. He is not in harmony with his surroundings.
He is adorned with grace. Perseverance brings good fortune.
He is adorned with grace. But he is limited. If he advances, he will meet with misfortune.
He is adorned with grace in the hills and gardens. He brings a roll of silk as a gift. Humiliation, but in the end good fortune.
Simple grace. No blame.

judgment: Splitting Apart. It does not further one to go anywhere.
image: The mountain rests on the earth: The image of Splitting Apart. Thus those above can ensure their position only by giving generously to those below.
lines: The bed is stripped of its legs. Those who persevere are destroyed. Misfortune.
The bed is stripped of its frame. Those who persevere are destroyed. Misfortune.
He strips them of their support. No blame.
The bed is stripped of its covering. Misfortune.
A string of fishes. Favor comes through the palace people. Nothing that would not further.
A large fruit is left uneaten. The superior man receives a carriage. The inferior man has his dwelling stripped away.

judgment: Return. Success. Going out and coming in without error. Friends come without blame. To and fro goes the way. On the seventh day comes the return. It furthers one to have somewhere to go.
image: Thunder within the earth: The image of Return. Thus the kings of old closed the passes at the time of the solstice. Merchants and strangers did not go about, and the ruler did not travel through the provinces.
lines: Return from a short distance. No need for remorse. Great good fortune.
Quiet return. Good fortune.
Repeated return. Danger. No blame.
Walking in the midst of others, he returns alone.
Noble return. No blame.

Missing the return. Misfortune. There will be calamities and mistakes. If armies are set marching, in the end there will be great defeat. The ruler of the country will suffer misfortune. It will bring misfortune for ten years.

judgment: Innocence. Supreme success. Perseverance furthers. If someone is not as he should be, he has misfortune, and it does not further him to undertake anything.
image: Under heaven, thunder is moving: The image of Innocence. Thus the kings of old, rich in virtue, were in harmony with the time, and fostered all beings.
lines: Innocent behavior brings good fortune.
If one does not count on the harvest while plowing, nor on the use of the ground while clearing it, it furthers one to undertake something.
Undeserved misfortune. The cow that was tied up by someone is the wanderer's gain. The people of the town suffer misfortune.
He who can remain persevering is without blame.
Do not use medicine in an illness incurred through no fault of your own. It will pass of itself.
Innocent behavior brings misfortune. Nothing that would further.

englishName: The Taming Power of the Great
judgment: The Taming Power of the Great. Perseverance furthers. It does not further one to eat at home. It furthers one to cross the great water.
image: Heaven within the mountain: The image of The Taming Power of the Great. Thus the superior man acquaints himself with many sayings of antiquity and many deeds of the past, in order to strengthen his character.
lines: Danger is at hand. It furthers one to desist.
The axle of the cart is taken off.
A good horse that follows others. Awareness of danger. Perseverance furthers. It furthers one to have somewhere to go.
The headboard of a young bull. Great good fortune.
The tusk of a castrated boar. Good fortune.
One attains the way of heaven. Success.

judgment: The Corners of the Mouth. Perseverance brings good fortune. Pay heed to the providing of nourishment and to what a man seeks to fill his own mouth.
image: At the foot of the mountain, thunder: The image of The Corners of the Mouth. Thus the superior man is careful of his words and temperate in eating and drinking.
lines: You let your magic tortoise go, and look at me with your mouth hanging open. Misfortune.
Turning to the summit for nourishment. Turning away from the hill for nourishment. Setting out to bring misfortune.
Turning away from nourishment. Perseverance brings misfortune. Do not act thus for ten years. Nothing that would further.
Turning to the summit for nourishment. Good fortune. Like a tiger eyeing his prey with fierce desire.
Turning away from nourishment. Living in a dwelling. Good fortune.
He does not seek to provide nourishment, but he is able to achieve it. Good fortune. It furthers one to cross the great water.

judgment: Preponderance of the Great. The ridgepole sags to the breaking point. It furthers one to have somewhere to go. Success.
image: The lake rises above the trees: The image of Preponderance of the Great. Thus the superior man, when he stands alone, is unconcerned, and if he has to renounce the world, he is undaunted.
lines: He lays soft grass underneath. No blame.
A dry willow sprouts at the root. An old man takes a young wife. Nothing that would further.
The ridgepole sags to the breaking point. Misfortune.
The ridgepole is in good condition. Humiliation.
A withered willow puts forth flowers. An old woman takes a young husband. No blame. No praise.
He wades through the water. It goes over his head. Misfortune. No blame.

judgment: The Abysmal repeated. If you are sincere, you have success in your heart. Action brings good fortune.
image: Water flows on uninterruptedly: The image of the Abysmal. Thus the superior man walks in constant virtue and carries on the business of instruction.
lines: Repeated abysses. In the abyss one falls into a pit. Misfortune.
The abyss is dangerous. One should seek small gains.
Forward and backward, abyss upon abyss. In danger, seek rest. Do not act thus.
A jug of wine, a dish of food, and a bowl of earthenware. They are accepted after all. No blame.
The abyss is not completely filled. It is only level with the edge. No blame.
He is bound with cords and ropes. He is placed in a thicket of thorns. For three years he does not find his way. Misfortune.

judgment: The Clinging Fire. Perseverance furthers. It brings success. Let the cow be kept. Good fortune.
image: Fire is attached to fire: The image of The Clinging Fire. Thus the great man, by perpetuating this brightness, illuminates the four quarters of the world.
lines: His steps are disordered. If he is respectful, no blame.
Yellow light. Supreme good fortune.
In the light of the setting sun, people either beat the pot and sing or else lament because of the approach of old age. Misfortune.
It comes all of a sudden. It flames up, dies down, and is thrown away.
Tears flow in torrents. Lamenting brings good fortune.
The king uses him to march forth and chastise. It is good to punish the leaders. He captures the rebels. No blame.

judgment: Influence. Success. Perseverance furthers. To take a maiden brings good fortune.
image: A lake on the mountain: The image of Influence. Thus the superior man encourages people to approach him by his humility.
lines: The influence of the big toe.
The influence of the calf of the leg. Misfortune. If one stays quiet, good fortune.
The influence of the thighs. He holds to what he follows. To go on brings humiliation.
Perseverance brings good fortune. Remorse disappears. If one goes on, one will be humiliated.
The influence of the back of the neck. No remorse.
The influence of the jaws and cheeks.

judgment: Duration. Success. No blame. Perseverance furthers. It furthers one to have somewhere to go.
image: Thunder and wind: The image of Duration. Thus the superior man stands firm and does not change his direction.
lines: Seeking duration in what is too deep. Misfortune. Nothing that would further.
Remorse disappears.
He who does not give duration to his character meets with humiliation.
No game in the field.
Giving duration to one's character through perseverance. Good fortune for a woman, misfortune for a man.
Restlessness as an expression of duration. Misfortune.

judgment: Retreat. Success. In small matters, perseverance furthers.
image: Under heaven, a mountain: The image of Retreat. Thus the superior man keeps the inferior man at a distance, not in anger but in dignity.
lines: Retreating tail. It is dangerous. One must not undertake anything.
He holds him fast with yellow oxhide. No one can tear him loose.
A retreat that is tied. To be sick is dangerous. To tend to servants and maids is good.
Voluntary retreat brings good fortune to the superior man. The inferior man cannot do this.
Friendly retreat. Perseverance brings good fortune.
A retreat that is rich. Nothing that would not further.

judgment: The Power of the Great. Perseverance furthers. The power of the great is correct. It is not correct to be like a ram that butts against a hedge. If one does not use one's power, one will meet with misfortune.
image: Thunder in heaven: The image of The Power of the Great. Thus the superior man does not tread paths that do not accord with the rules. He does not overstep the bounds of what is right.
lines: Power in the toes. Going on brings misfortune. This is certainly true.
Perseverance brings good fortune.
The inferior man uses his power. The superior man does not use it. Perseverance brings danger. A ram butts against a hedge; his horns get caught.
Perseverance brings good fortune. Remorse disappears. The hedge is broken open. The power is not used. It is good to be like a great wagon.
He loses the ram in the easygoing way. No remorse.
A ram butts against a hedge; he cannot go either forward or backward. Nothing that would further. If one is aware of the difficulty, this brings good fortune.

judgment: Progress. The powerful prince is offered horses in great numbers. In a single day he is granted audience three times.
image: The sun rises over the earth: The image of Progress. Thus the superior man himself brightens his bright virtue.
lines: Progressing, but turned back. Perseverance brings good fortune. If one is trusted, one need not be concerned.
Progressing, but in sorrow. Perseverance brings good fortune. One receives this great blessing from one's grandmother.
All are in accord. Remorse disappears.
Progressing like a hamster. Perseverance brings danger.
Remorse disappears. Do not worry about either gain or loss. Undertakings bring good fortune.
Progressing with horns. It is good to use them to chastise one's own city. Danger. Good fortune. No blame. Perseverance brings humiliation.

judgment: Darkening of the Light. In adversity it furthers one to be persevering.
image: The sun has sunk into the earth: The image of Darkening of the Light. Thus the superior man lives with the great mass: he veils his light, yet still shines.
lines: Darkening of the light during flight. He lowers his wings. The superior man does not eat for three days. He has somewhere to go. The host has something to say about him.
Darkening of the light injures his left thigh. He uses the strength of a horse. Good fortune.
Darkening of the light during the hunt in the south. He captures their great leader. One must not be impatient.
He penetrates into the left side of the belly. He obtains the heart of the darkening of the light. He goes out of the gate and the courtyard.
Darkening of the light as with King Chi. It furthers one to be persevering.
Not light, but darkness. First he ascends to heaven, then he plunges into the depths of the earth.

judgment: The Family. The perseverance of the woman furthers. It furthers one to be persevering.
image: Wind comes forth from fire: The image of The Family. Thus the superior man's words must have substance, and his actions must be consistent.
lines: Firmness in the family. Remorse disappears.
She should not follow her whims. She must attend to the food in the house. Perseverance brings good fortune.
When the family is in disorder, there is remorse and humiliation.
Enriching the family brings great good fortune.
The king approaches his family. Do not be anxious. Good fortune.
Sincerity is the source of dignity. In the end good fortune comes.

judgment: Opposition. In small matters, good fortune.
image: Fire moves upward, the lake moves downward: The image of Opposition. Thus amid all fellowship the superior man retains his individuality.
lines: Remorse disappears. If one loses one's horse, do not pursue it; it will come back of its own accord. When one sees evil people, one is free of blame.
One meets one's lord in a narrow street. No blame.
One sees the wagon being pulled back. The oxen are held back. His nose is cut off. This is not a good beginning, but there is a good end.
Opposition. He is isolated. He meets a good man. They are sincere with each other. Danger. No blame.
Remorse disappears. His companion bites his way through the skin. If one goes to him, how could there be blame?

Opposition. He is isolated. He sees his companion as a pig covered with mud. He sees him as a wagon full of devils. First he draws his bow, then he lays it aside. He is not a robber. He goes to meet him. Rain comes. Good fortune.

judgment: Obstruction. The southwest furthers. The northeast does not further. It furthers one to see the great man. Perseverance brings good fortune.
image: Water on the mountain: The image of Obstruction. Thus the superior man turns his attention to his own character.
lines: Going forward meets with obstruction. Coming back brings praise.
The king's servant is obstructed. It is not his fault.
Going forward meets with obstruction. He comes back.
Going forward meets with obstruction. He comes back. He makes friends with the one who is obstructed.
Great obstruction. Friends come.
Going forward meets with obstruction. Coming back brings good fortune. It furthers one to see the great man.

judgment: Deliverance. The southwest furthers. If there is no place to go, the return brings good fortune. If there is a place to go, it brings good fortune. If one acts quickly, good fortune.
image: Thunder and rain set in: The image of Deliverance. Thus the superior man pardons mistakes and forgives misdeeds.
lines: Without blame.
In the field one hunts three foxes and obtains yellow arrows. Perseverance brings good fortune.
If a man carries a burden on his back and rides in a carriage, he attracts robbers. Perseverance brings humiliation.
Deliverance from your big toe. Then your companions will come. If you are sincere, you will be believed.
If the superior man is able to deliver himself, he will be believed by the inferior man.
The prince shoots a hawk on a high wall. He kills it. Everything acts to further.

judgment: Decrease combined with sincerity brings supreme good fortune. No blame. One may be persevering in this. It furthers one to undertake something. How is this to be done? One may use two small bowls for the sacrifice.
image: At the foot of the mountain, the lake: The image of Decrease. Thus the superior man controls his anger and restrains his desires.
lines: If one is to accomplish a decrease, one must act quickly. No blame. Consider how much to decrease.
It furthers one to be persevering. Undertakings bring misfortune. Without decreasing oneself, one can increase others.
Three men journey together. Their number is decreased by one. One man journeys alone. He finds his companion.
If one decreases one's sickness, one will be happy. No blame.
Someone increases him. Ten pairs of tortoises cannot oppose this. Supreme good fortune.
If one does not decrease, one will increase. No blame.

judgment: Increase. It furthers one to undertake something. It furthers one to cross the great water.
image: Wind and thunder: The image of Increase. Thus the superior man, when he sees good, imitates it; and when he has faults, he reforms them.
lines: It furthers one to undertake great deeds. Supreme good fortune. No blame.
Someone increases him. Ten pairs of tortoises cannot oppose this. Constant perseverance brings good fortune. The king offers a sacrifice to God. Good fortune.
One is increased through misfortune. No blame. If one is sincere, one will be in the center. If one goes on, one will be in the center. It furthers one to undertake something.
If one is in the center, one will be believed. If one goes on, one will be in the center. It furthers one to undertake something.
If one is sincere, one will be in the center. Do not ask. Supreme good fortune. One will be believed.
He does not increase anyone. Someone attacks him. He does not set his heart on it. Misfortune.

judgment: Break-through. One must resolutely make the matter known in the royal court. It must be announced truthfully. Danger. One must tell one's own city. It does not further one to take up arms. It furthers one to undertake something.
image: The lake rises up to heaven: The image of Break-through. Thus the superior man distributes riches below and avoids resting on his virtue.
lines: Power in the toes. Going on brings misfortune. This is certainly true.
Awareness of danger. At night one must not take up arms. No blame.
A superior man is resolute. He walks alone. He meets with rain. He is angry. He is without blame.
He has no skin on his thighs. He walks with difficulty. If one is led like a sheep, remorse disappears.
The weeds are not yet cut. He walks with difficulty. No blame.
He has no skin on his head. Misfortune.

judgment: Coming to Meet. The maiden is powerful. One must not marry such a maiden.
image: Under heaven, the wind: The image of Coming to Meet. Thus the ruler makes his commands known throughout the four quarters of the world.
lines: He is held back by a brake of metal. Perseverance brings good fortune. If one goes on, one will meet with misfortune. A lean pig is restless.
There is a fish in the tank. No blame. It does not further one to undertake anything.
He has no skin on his thighs. He walks with difficulty. Danger. No great blame.
There is no fish in the tank. Misfortune.
He wraps melon in willow leaves. There is a hidden pattern. Then it falls to him from heaven.
He meets with horns. Humiliation. No blame.

judgment: Gathering Together. Success. The king approaches his temple. It furthers one to see the great man. This brings success. Perseverance furthers. To offer great sacrifices brings good fortune. It furthers one to undertake something.
image: The lake rises up out of the earth: The image of Gathering Together. Thus the superior man arms himself against unforeseen events.
lines: If you are sincere, but not to the end, you will sometimes be confused, sometimes gathered together. If you cry out, one grasp of the hand will bring a smile. Do not be concerned. To go on brings no blame.
If one is sincere, one will be in the center. This brings good fortune. If one is sincere, one may offer a sacrifice. This brings good fortune.
Gathering together with sighs. Nothing that would further. To go on brings no blame. Slight humiliation.
Great good fortune. No blame.
If one is in the center, one will be believed. No blame. If one is sincere, one will be in the center. This brings good fortune.
Sighing and weeping. No blame.

judgment: Pushing Upward has supreme success. One must see the great man. Do not be anxious. Setting out toward the south brings good fortune.
image: Wood grows in the earth: The image of Pushing Upward. Thus the superior man of devoted character accumulates small things in order to achieve great heights.
lines: Pushing upward that meets with trust. Great good fortune.
If one is sincere, one may offer a sacrifice. This brings good fortune. No blame.
Pushing upward into an empty city.
Pushing upward that is not in the right place.
Pushing upward that is not in the right place. Perseverance brings good fortune.
Pushing upward in darkness. It furthers one to be unceasingly persevering.

judgment: Oppression. Success. Perseverance. The great man brings good fortune. No blame. If one has something to say, one will not be believed.
image: There is no water in the lake: The image of Oppression. Thus the superior man stakes his life on his will.
lines: He is oppressed by a bare tree. He enters a dark valley. For three years he does not see the light.
He is oppressed by wine and food. The red knee bands are just coming. It furthers one to offer a sacrifice. Undertakings bring misfortune. No blame.
He is oppressed by a rock. He leans on thorns. He enters his house and does not see his wife. Misfortune.
He comes very slowly. He is oppressed by a golden carriage. Humiliation, but in the end good fortune.
His nose and feet are cut off. He is oppressed by the red knee bands. He is happy. It furthers one to offer a sacrifice.
He is oppressed by creepers. He moves about uneasily. If one says, 'Movement brings remorse,' there will be remorse.

judgment: The Well. The town may be changed, but the well cannot be changed. It does not decrease, it does not increase. They come and go, and the well is always there. If the well is not used, it is a misfortune. If the well is used, it is a blessing.
image: Water above wood: The image of The Well. Thus the superior man encourages the people at their work, and exhorts them to help one another.
lines: One does not drink the mud of the well. No animals come to an old well.
At the wellhole one shoots fishes. The jug is broken and leaks.
The well is cleaned, but no one drinks from it. This is my heart's sorrow, for one might draw from it. If the king were clear-minded, good fortune might be enjoyed.
The well is being lined. No blame.
In the well there is a clear, cold spring from which one can drink.
The well is capped. One cannot drink from it.

judgment: Revolution. On your own day, you are believed. Sublime success, furthering through perseverance. Remorse disappears.
image: Fire in the lake: The image of Revolution. Thus the superior man sets the calendar in order and makes the seasons clear.
lines: Bound with the hide of a yellow ox.
When the time is ripe, one may make revolution. Good fortune. No blame.
Undertaking brings misfortune. Perseverance brings danger.
Remorse vanishes. Because one is believed, the ordinance is changed. Good fortune.
The great man changes like a tiger. Even before he consults the oracle he is believed.
The superior man changes like a panther. The inferior man molts his face. To go on brings misfortune. To remain brings good fortune.

judgment: The Cauldron. Sublime good fortune. Success.
image: Fire over wood: The image of The Cauldron. Thus the superior man consolidates his fate by making his position correct.
lines: A cauldron with legs upturned. Furthering to dispose of the old. One obtains concubines through this. Her son is without blemish.
There are contents in the cauldron. My enemy is sick, unable to come to me. Good fortune.
The handle of the cauldron is changed.
The legs of the cauldron are broken. The prince's meal is spilled, and his person is soiled. Misfortune.
A cauldron with yellow handles, with rings of metal.
The jade rings of the cauldron. Great good fortune. Nothing that would not further.

judgment: The Arousing brings success. Shock comes - oh, oh! Laughing words - ha, ha! The shock terrifies for a hundred miles, and yet he does not let fall the sacrificial spoon and chalice.
image: Thunder repeated: The image of The Arousing. Thus in fear and trembling the superior man sets his life in order and examines himself.
lines: Shock comes - oh, oh! Afterwards comes laughter - ha, ha! Good fortune.
Shock comes and brings danger. A hundred thousand times you lose your treasures and must climb the nine hills. Do not go in pursuit of them. After seven days you will get them back.
Shock comes and makes one distraught. If shock spurs to action one remains free of blame.
Shock comes like a quagmire.
Shock goes hither and thither. Danger.
Shock brings ruin and terrified cries. If one sets about righting things, there will be no blame.

judgment: Keeping His Back Still, so that he no longer feels his body. He goes into his courtyard and does not see his people. No blame.
image: Mountains standing close together: The image of Keeping Still. Thus the superior man does not go beyond his thoughts.
lines: Keeping his toes still. No blame. Continued perseverance brings good fortune.
Keeping his calves still. He cannot rescue him whom he follows. His heart is not glad.
Keeping his loins still, wrenching his back.
Keeping his body still. No blame.
Keeping his jaws still. The words have order. Occasion for regret disappears.
Noblehearted keeping still. Good fortune.

judgment: Development. The maiden is given in marriage. Good fortune. Perseverance furthers.
image: On the mountain, a tree: The image of Development. Thus the superior man abides in dignity and virtue, in order to improve customs.
lines: The wild goose gradually draws near the shore. The young son is endangered. There is talk.
The wild goose gradually draws near the cliff. Eating and drinking in peace and concord. Good fortune.
The wild goose gradually draws near the plateau. The husband goes forth and does not return. The wife is with child but does not nourish it. Misfortune. It furthers one to ward off robbers.
The wild goose gradually draws near the tree. Perhaps it will find a flat branch.
The wild goose gradually draws near the height. For three years the wife does not bear a child, and in the end she cannot withstand it. Good fortune.
The wild goose gradually draws near the clouds. Its feathers can be used for the sacred dance. Good fortune.

judgment: The Marrying Maiden. Undertakings bring misfortune. Nothing that would further.
image: Thunder over the lake: The image of The Marrying Maiden. Thus the superior man understands the transitory nature of all earthly existence.
lines: The marrying maiden as a concubine. A lame man is able to tread.
A one-eyed man is able to see. The perseverance of a solitary man furthers.
The marrying maiden as a slave. She takes her place in the train as a concubine.
The marrying maiden tarries. If late she marries, the time will be proper.
The sleeves of the marrying maiden are not as good as the sleeves of the woman who is belatedly getting married.
The woman holds the basket, but there are no fruits in it. The officiating priest holds the animal for sacrifice, but it is without blemish.

judgment: Abundance has success. The king arrives at his temple. Be not sad. Be like the sun at midday.
image: Both thunder and lightning come: The image of Abundance. Thus the superior man decides lawsuits and carries out punishments.
lines: Meeting his mate. Though they are both of like nature, this bodes no blame. Going forward brings causes for regret.
Abundance of the curtain. One sees the bushel basket at midday. If one goes, one will be met with mistrust and dislike. One should be like the sun at midday.
Abundance of the undergrowth. One breaks his right arm. No blame.
Meeting his mate. Though they are both of like nature, this bodes no blame. Going forward brings causes for regret.
Abundance of the curtain. One sees the bushel basket at midday. If one goes, one will be met with mistrust and dislike. One should be like the sun at midday.
Abundance of the undergrowth. One breaks his right arm. No blame.
Abundance of the curtain. At midday one beholds the polestars. Meeting one's like brings good fortune.
Lines are coming, embellished. Good fortune.
His house is in a state of abundance. One sees his courtyard shut off and still. He peers through the gate. No men are to be seen. For three years no one takes any notice of him. Misfortune.

judgment: The Wanderer. Success through smallness. Perseverance brings good fortune.
image: Fire on the mountain: The image of The Wanderer. Thus the superior man makes his judgments clear and careful, and does not protract litigations.
lines: If the wanderer busies himself with trifles, he draws down misfortune upon himself.
The wanderer arrives at his lodging. He has his means of livelihood with him. He wins the adherence of the young servant.
The wanderer rests in a beautiful place. He still has his servants with him.
The wanderer rests in a lodging. He obtains средства and an axe. My heart is not glad.
Shooting a pheasant, it drops at one shot. In the end this brings honor and fame.
The bird's nest burns up. The wanderer laughs at first, then he has cause to lament.

judgment: The Gentle. Success through smallness. It furthers one to have somewhere to go. It furthers one to see the great man.
image: Winds following one upon the other: The image of The Gentle. Thus the superior man spreads his commands abroad and carries out his undertakings.
lines: Penetration under the bed. The chr
Penetration under the bed. On the ceremonial table are laid out the offerings. Those who decide on this will use them. No blame.
Repeated penetration. Humiliation.
Remorse vanishes. During the hunt he obtains threefold game.
Perseverance brings good fortune. Occasion for regret disappears. Nothing that would not further. No beginning, but an end. Before the change, three days. After the change, three days. Good fortune.
Penetration under the bed. He loses his means of livelihood. Perseverance brings misfortune.

judgment: The Joyous. Success. Perseverance furthers.
image: Lakes joining together: The image of The Joyous. Thus the superior man joins with his friends for discussion and practice.
lines: Contentment in the marsh. Good fortune.
Sincere contentment. Good fortune. Occasion for regret disappears.
Coming contentment. Misfortune.
Joyousness that is weighed is not at peace. After breaking through, he finds joy.
Sincerity toward the disintegrating. Danger.
Seductive joyousness.

judgment: Dispersion. Success. The king approaches his temple. It furthers one to cross the great water. Perseverance furthers.
image: The wind drives over the water: The image of Dispersion. Thus the kings of old sacrificed to the Lord and established temples.
lines: Saving with the strength of a horse.
At the dissolution he hurries to his support. Remorse disappears.
He dissolves his self. No occasion for regret.
He breaks up his group. Supreme good fortune. Dispersion means the dispersal of what is harmful. When what is harmful is done away with, individually small things become important.
As sweat flows from the body, so are words dispersed. No blame.
He dissolves his blood. Depart, keep at a distance, avoid blame.

judgment: Limitation. Success. Bitter limitation cannot be persevered in.
image: Water over the lake: The image of Limitation. Thus the superior man creates number and measure, and examines the nature of virtue and correct conduct.
lines: Not going out of the door and the courtyard is without blame.
Not going out of the door and the courtyard brings misfortune.
He who knows limitation is freed from sorrow.
Contented limitation. Success.
Sweet limitation, good fortune. Going brings esteem.
Grievous limitation. Perseverance brings misfortune. Occasion for regret disappears.

judgment: Inner Truth. Pigs and fishes. Good fortune. It furthers one to cross the great water. Perseverance furthers.
image: Wind over the lake: The image of Inner Truth. Thus the superior man discusses cases in order to delay executions.
lines: Being prepared brings good fortune. If one has secret plans, one will be disturbed.
A crane calling in the shade. Her young answers her. I have a good goblet. I will share it with you.
He finds a comrade. Now he beats the drum or stops.
The moon nearly at the full. The horses of the team stray. No blame.
He has an inner truth that binds him like a bond. No blame.
The cockcrow mounts to heaven. Continued perseverance brings misfortune.

judgment: Small Preponderance. Success. Perseverance furthers. Small things may be done. Not the great bird, but the flying bird.
image: Thunder on the mountain: The image of Small Preponderance. Thus the superior man in his conduct gives preponderance to reverence. In mourning, he gives preponderance to grief.
lines: The bird flying by leaves behind the sound. The superior man does not go forth; he remains in his room. No blame.
Passing her by, he goes to meet her lord. This does not further his ministers.
Careful not to go too far. From him one could even rob. Determination furthers.
Without meeting him, he passes him by. Going forward is dangerous. One must be cautious. Do not act.
Dense clouds, no rain from our western border. The prince shoots and hits him in the cave.
He meets him and passes him by. The flying bird leaves him. This means misfortune. This is called willful blindness.

judgment: After Completion. Success in small matters. Perseverance furthers. At the beginning, good fortune. At the end, disorder.
image: Water over fire: The image of After Completion. Thus the superior man takes thought of misfortune and arms himself against it in advance.
lines: He drags his wheels. He wets his tail. No blame.
A woman loses her curtain. Do not chase it; on the seventh day you will find it.
The Illustrious Ancestor chastises the demon country. After three years he conquers it. Inferior people must not be employed.
He has fine robes, but he sees himself perpetually put to hardship. All day long he is on his guard.
The neighbor in the east who slaughters an ox does not attain as much real happiness as the neighbor in the west who makes a small offering.
He gets his head in the water. Danger.

judgment: Before Completion. Success. But if the little fox, when he has almost completed the crossing, gets his tail wet, there will be nothing that furthers.
image: Fire over water: The image of Before Completion. Thus the superior man is careful in the discrimination of things and the allotting of them to their proper places.
lines: He wets his tail. Humiliation.
He brakes his wheels. Perseverance brings good fortune.
Before completion, attack brings misfortune. It furthers one to cross the great water.
Perseverance brings good fortune. Remorse disappears. Shake the land of demons. For three years great rewards are conferred on him in this country.
The light of the superior man is glorious. There is good fortune.
He is confident and drinks wine. No blame. But if he wets his head, he loses his confidence.
